Author: edu
Content: I don't know about this case, but keep in mind that editors can rewrite submission titles. Check: http://ycombinator.com/newsguidelines.html

Author: simonw
Content:
I disagree: just like Ajax, Comet is a very necessary buzzword. The technology behind Comet existed for years before the term "Comet" was coined, but very few developers were aware of it because there wasn't a good term for it. The same is true of Ajax. In fact, Comet was coined precisely because the term "Ajax" had had such a large influence on adoption of the underlying technology.

Vocabulary is important.

Author: davidw
Content: It seems as if Comet is more important than your startup.  Maybe a startup isn't the right way to promote Comet, if Comet is truly what's important to you?

Author: edw519
Content:
"They're not going to tell the CEO that they're no longer relevant"

Author: transburgh
Title: It's Gonna Blow! The Critical Mass of Web 2.0

Author: edw519
Content:
"Math is to learning what endurance and strength training is to sports: the basis that enables you to excel in the specialty of your choice. You cannot become a major sports star without being strong and having good cardiovascular ability. You cannot become a star within your job or excel in your profession unless you can think smart and critically -- and math will help you do that."

That's the best articulation of this idea I've ever seen.

The article could have (and should have) stopped after this.

Author: simonw
Content: I wrote more about this here: http://simonwillison.net/2007/Dec/5/comet/

Author: simonw
Content:
The JavaScript you described exists - it's called dojox.comet, and it looks like this:

dojox.cometd.init('http://example.com/cometd');\ndojox.cometd.subscribe('/channel', callback);

That's basically what you described, but with the additional concept of "channels" to make it easy to support lots of different event streams.

Author: jmzachary
Content:
I'm 38. I started my company last week on Jan 2.

Age is a state of mind. I see 20 somethings thinking like 50 somethings, and 30+ somethings thinking like 20 somethings. What you do with that state of mind is what counts.

Author: nailer
Title: A light hearted look at the great format wars of our time
Content:
Another great format war ended this week, with Blu-Ray to 70% of released films and, according to the Financial Times, HD-DVD left with one major studio.

We've been here before: whether RealPlayer versus Windows Media, BSD versus Linux, or boxers versus briefs. Let's take a look back at some of the great format wars of our time.
